topic.title: M3: Content Question (X86 Processor Architecture)
topic.msg: Post questions about X-86 processor architecture. Use the first line of your post as the subject of the post.

entry.title: loose llama
entry.msg:
Why can't memory operations be implemented with 2 steps instead of 4?

From the Assembly Language for x86 textbook, it says:

"2.1.3 Reading from Memory
...reading a single value from memory involves four separate steps:
1. Place the address of the value you want to read on the address bus.
2. Assert (change the value of) the processorâ€™s RD (read) pin.
3. Wait one clock cycle for the memory chips to respond.
4. Copy the data from the data bus into the destination operand."

QUESTIONS:

  1. Why can't operations 1 and 2 be combined (place address value on bus and set RD pin simultaneously)?
  2. Why can't operation 3 write data directly into the destination operand (REG/ALU) to eliminate step 4)?

I understand these are CPU hardware questions that don't really relate to ASM software.  But this section is on CPU architecture and I'm curious why there needs to be 4 steps for the hardware to read memory.

entry.title: fixed frog
entry.msg: I believe this is an issue with hardware limitations and how the memory is made to function to prevent overflow and corruption. Not 100% sure, but A can't happen physically because memory addresses and memory storage are two different things. They are not the same. The machine loads the "address", finds "address", and then goes to this address. B is due to how memory is handled, in this instance all memory is stack-based. Once the memory is loaded into the stack, it needs to check if it can go off the stack. Different memory systems have different limitations. For instance, a hard drive only spins one way so it needs to cycle again to go back in memory.

entry.title: spatial snipe
entry.msg: This is certainly the limitation of Hardware. Since electrical signals and clock controls the processes, you can do only one action per clock cycle, read or store or add.  All these low level instructions on how to read memory or how to store memory gives immense power to write the programs efficiently at the same time, it can be super lengthy.  However as we move up to higher level languages, all these low level actions are abstracted and we never need to worry about those details, but at the cost we need to give into limitations of high-level languages like C, C++, Java etc.   For your query about combining steps, it may be possible with redesigned hardware processors, but I am not sure if they will be feasible enough, otherwise all these improvements might have been done since the processor industry has come a long way.

entry.title: faithful firefly
entry.msg: If you combined the step of changing the read pin and writing out the hardware address, you might have a race condition where the read pin is changed before the address is changed, and the memory would fetch the wrong address. Because the smallest unit of machine time is the clock cycle, it might be infeasible to subdivide a single clock cycle into waiting for an address writing-out state and then completing a read pin changing state. Besides, as is mentioned in the book a lot of this lengthiness is mitigated by the fact that caching exists.

entry.title: consistent centipede
entry.msg: Does anyone know how to set up MASM with Mac?

entry.title: surviving takin
entry.msg:
On your Mac, go to Amazon (Links to an external site.), buy a Windows PC, then set up MASM.

 

Jokes aside, MASM (quite literally) is a Microsoft product and isn't designed for Mac. There are clever workarounds though and there are instructions on #resources in the Discord server that will get you set up (credit to Ronak for that)

entry.title: supposed swordtail
entry.msg:
I posted this in #resources of the discord but I'll paste it here as well.

use this link: https://reberhardt.com/blog/programming/2016/01/30/masm-on-mac-or-linux.html (Links to an external site.)

use http://masm32.masmcode.com/masm32/masm32v11r.zip (Links to an external site.) instead of the link to masm they give in the guide

and finally, replace the Irvine installation commands in the blog with

curl -o Irvine.zip "http://asmirvine.com/gettingStartedVS2019/Irvine.zip"
unzip Irvine.zip
cp -r irvine ~/wine-masm/drive_c/Irvine

entry.title: consistent centipede
entry.msg: Thank you, Ronak!

entry.title: close buzzard
entry.msg:
Hi Michael,

There are many ways, but you can't run MASM on macOS directly without doing very complicated workarounds.

 

The easiest way is using Boot Camp if you have an Intel chip to run Windows. If you have an M1, you can use a VM like Parallels, but you need to pay and join the Windows Insider program to get the ARM version of Windows.

entry.title: passive owl
entry.msg:
Virtual-8086 mode

I am not very understanding of the Virtual-8086 mode. The PowerPoint mentioned it's a "hybrid of Protected". What is the relationship and/or difference between Virtual-8086 mode and Protected mode?

entry.title: statutory squirrel
entry.msg:
I believe that the Virtual-8086 mode is a mode that runs in the protected mode. In other words, its not really a full-fledged mode. Pretty sure its made to execute 16-bit program in a 32-bit protected mode (according to the source I used). There is also some info in our textbook.

Some resources:

https://titanwolf.org/Network/Articles/Article?AID=fc636498-769a-4fcc-8722-6ec8cf06b906#gsc.tab=0 (Links to an external site.)

entry.title: grumpy haddock
entry.msg: I think that the relationship between virtual-8086 mode and protected mode is that the virtual-8086 mode is a submode of protected mode, where it runs in protected mode but can directly execute real-address mode things.

entry.title: financial fowl
entry.msg: The Virtual 8086 Mode lets real mode applications be executed which are incapable of running in the protected mode. Basically it lets the operating system switch between running protected modes and non protected modes.

entry.title: genuine gopher
entry.msg:
64-Bit General purpose registers

What's the difference between the 32-bit general purpose registers and the 64-bit purpose registers?

entry.title: tough toad
entry.msg: I think a 32-bit general purpose register can access 2^32 memory addresses while a 64 bit purpose register can access 2^64 memory addresses.

entry.title: Cole Gannon
entry.msg: The difference between 32 bit registers and 64 bit registers is that 64 bit registers are bigger and can be used for 64 bit instructions and system calls.

entry.title: overseas orca
entry.msg:
To further elaborate on Nikita's reply, a useful link: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/difference-32-bit-64-bit-operating-systems/ (Links to an external site.)

The number of bits determines the amount of memory addresses a register has: i.e: a 32-bit general purpose register would have 2^32 memory addresses.

entry.title: loose llama
entry.msg:
Protected Mode hardware access?

In Protected Mode, the system can run multiple programs at once, each program can access 4GB of memory space and process memory can be protected from access by other processes.  But the book says that Protected Mode cannot directly access any hardware.  Virtual-8086 Mode cannot access hardware either.

According to this Protection and I/O (Links to an external site.) reference it should be possible for Protected Mode to access hardware via an "I/O Permission" bit map.

Is it possible for Protected Mode to access hardware or not?  If not, does the processor need to temporarily enter Real-Addressing Mode?  Why?

entry.title: hilarious harrier
entry.msg:
The Auxiliary Carry flag (AC) is set when an arithmetic operation causes a carry from bit 3
to bit 4 in an 8-bit operand

 

Why is there a specific flag just for this?

entry.title: conscious cattle
entry.msg:
The Auxiliary carry flag has a similar idea as carry flag, except it indicates a decimal carry or borrow which is useful to represent binary coded decimal (BCD) digits.

Have a look at this article.
https://www.tutorialspoint.com/flags-register-in-8085-microprocessor (Links to an external site.)

entry.title: enormous earthworm
entry.msg:
Components of a Typical x86 Computer

Why does the 8253 Programmable Interval Timer/Counter have the timing 18.2 times per second?

entry.title: insufficient junglefowl
entry.msg:
counter 0 is the time of day interrupt and is generated approximately 18.2 times per sec. The value 18.2 is derived from the frequency 1.10318/65536 (the normal default count).

here is some additional information: http://staff.ustc.edu.cn/~xyfeng/research/cos/resources/BIOS/Resources/assembly/8253.html

entry.title: entitled earwig
entry.msg:
Accessing parts of registers

I didn't really understand the concept of EAX, EBX, ECX, EDX, etc. What are these? And what is their purpose? I completely lost understanding of the subject when they mentioned those in the PowerPoint.

entry.title: relaxed python
entry.msg:
The EAX, EBX, ECX, EDX, EBP, EDI, and ESI registers are all 32-bit general-purpose registers, used for temporary data storage and memory access. I recommend you to read this website for the further understanding for each registers:

https://web.archive.org/web/20191114093028/https://gerardnico.com/computer/cpu/register/general

entry.title: advanced anaconda
entry.msg:
For General-purpose registers, why we do not have 16-bit upper half access as we do for the 8-bit upper half?

EAX - 32 bit

AX - lower 16 bit

AH - upper 8 bit

AL - lower 8 bit

entry.title: entitled earwig
entry.msg:
Purpose of Sign Status Flag

In the previous chapter, we learned that in 2's complement, the sign bit is used to indicate sign. Then, what is the purpose of the sign status flag? Is it just for convenience?

entry.title: driving deer
entry.msg:
Hi Kavan,

I believe that the sign bit, which is used to indicate whether a 2's complement number is positive or negative, from a resulting mathematical operation helps set the sign status flag. If the sign bit of the resulting number is 1, then the sign status flag is set to 1. Contrastingly, if the sign bit is 0 and the resulting number is positive, then the sign status flag is set to 0. Since the bit for the flag is stored inside a register in the CPU, I believe that it is important for the processor when executing instructions. Wikipedia has a nice explanation of the sign flag: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_flag (Links to an external site.)
